translated: 5. Explanation of the Stages of the Perfection of DhyÄna, Scroll 9
Expounded by the Great Master Zhizhe of Tiantai in the Sui Dynasty
Recorded by disciple Fashan

Disciple Guanding re-edited and explained the seventh part of the cultivation and realization of the perfection of meditation, which clarifies the cultivation and realization of the undefiled meditation.
Now, the undefiled is explained in two ways.
First, the undefiled of counteraction.
Second, the undefiled of contemplating the principle.
Therefore, the MahÄsaá¹ƒnipÄta SÅ«tra says:
There are two kinds of practices.
First, the practice of wisdom.
Second, the practice of practice.
The practice of practice.
This is the undefiled of counteraction such as the nine visualizations and the emancipations.
Because the practice that arises from contemplating phenomena is used to counteract and destroy the afflictions,
It is called the practice of the undefiled practice.
Second, the practice of wisdom.
This is the four noble truths.
Because the correct contemplation of the emptiness of the twelve links of dependent arising contemplates the principle and severs delusions,
It is called the practice of the undefiled practice of wisdom.
The first is the explanation of the undefiled of counteraction.
This is clarified using the nine kinds of Dharma gates.
First, the nine visualizations.
Second, the eight recollections.
Thirty thoughts.
Four kinds of eight liberations.
Five kinds of eight spheres of mastery. Six kinds of all pervading bases.
Seven kinds of nine successive concentrations.
Eight kinds of lion's exertion samÄdhi.
Nine kinds of surpassing samÄdhi.
Now these nine kinds of dhyÄna are generally called the uncontaminated path of counteraction.
And the meaning of the shallow and deep sequence is all as explained above.
In the first fascicle.
Now within these nine kinds of Dharma gates.
There are two kinds of uncontaminated paths of counteraction.
The first is the path of destruction.
The second is the path of non-destruction.
The path of destruction refers to the nine thoughts, eight recollections, and ten thoughts.
If one skillfully cultivates these three.
If one gives rise to true uncontaminated [wisdom].
One will then become an arhat whose dharmas are subject to destruction.
The second is the path of non-destruction.
This refers to the eight liberations, eight spheres of mastery, ten universal bases, nine successive concentrations, lion's exertion samÄdhi, surpassing samÄdhi, and so forth.
One who is fully endowed with this dhyÄna.
And attain true undefiled liberation, becoming an arhat whose liberation is unshakable.
Now, I will explain in general the three kinds of methods in the first contemplation of the dharma of decay.
The reason these three methods are called the contemplation of the dharma of decay is that
the practitioner's mind is disgusted with the six desires, which are like enemies and thieves.
Therefore, they cultivate the nine visualizations as a remedy.
When practicing this contemplation, although they destroy the six desires, they often give rise to fear.
If they cultivate the eight kinds of right mindfulness, fear is immediately eliminated.
When the mind of greed and desire is thin and there is no fear,
at that time, if they want to sever the bonds of the three realms, they should then progress and cultivate the ten visualizations.
When the ten visualizations are accomplished,
they will then kill the thieves of the bonds and become an arhat.
This person, having already destroyed the physical characteristics of the desire realm,
is unable to fully cultivate the three realms, the three insights, the eight liberations, and so forth.
Therefore, it is called
the dharma of decay. Question: What is the difference between the nine visualizations and the ten visualizations?
Answer:
There is both difference and non-difference.
The difference is that the nine contemplations are like binding a thief,
while the ten contemplations are like killing a thief.
The nine contemplations are for beginners,
while the ten contemplations are for accomplishment.
The nine contemplations are the cause,
while the ten contemplations are the effect.
Therefore, the sutra says:
The two are the gates to immortality.
The first is the gate of contemplation of impurity,
and the second is the gate of mindfulness of breathing.
As for not being different, if one skillfully cultivates the nine contemplations,
one will be fully endowed with the ten contemplations.
This meaning will be clarified below.ğŸ”½First, the explanation of the nine contemplations.
The first is the contemplation of bloating,
the second is the contemplation of decay,
the third is the contemplation of blood-smeared,
the fourth is the contemplation of pus-filled,
the fifth is the contemplation of bluish-black,
the sixth is the contemplation of being eaten,
the seventh is the contemplation of scattering,
the eighth is the contemplation of bones,
and the ninth is the contemplation of burning.

These nine kinds of methods are collectively called contemplations because they can transform the mind and transform thoughts, that is, they can transform the inverted thoughts of purity within impurity.
Therefore, they are called contemplations.
Now, the nine contemplations are explained.
It is then divided into four meanings.ğŸ”½First, clarifying cultivation and realization.
Second, clarifying countermeasures.
Third, clarifying the inclusion of dharmas.
Fourth, clarifying the approach to the path.
First, clarifying cultivation and realization.
The practitioner first upholds pure precepts, causing the mind to be free from regret and easily accepting the methods of contemplation.
It can destroy the thieves of desire and various afflictions.
Therefore, at that time, one should first contemplate.
When a person first dies, their words and speech stop, and they suddenly die, with their breath extinguished and the body cold, without any awareness.
The family is shocked and wails to the heavens, crying out in grief.
Their words are just like this, and they suddenly depart. Where have they gone?
This is a great fear.
There is no one who can escape it.
It is like the fire that burns at the end of the eon, leaving nothing behind.
As a verse says:
When death arrives, there is no poverty or wealth, no diligence in cultivating good dharmas
No nobility or lowliness, no young or old who can escape it
No prayers that can save, no place to deceive
There is no one who can escape it, all are unable to avoid it.
The law of death is called the place of eternal separation from loved ones, which all living beings detest.
Although it is known to be detestable, there is no one who can avoid it.
My body will not last long and will certainly be like this.
The same as wood and stone, without any distinction or knowledge.
I should not now greedily cling to the five desires, unaware that death will come, the same as cattle and sheep.
Cattle, sheep, and beasts, although they see death, they jump and roar without realizing it themselves.
I have already obtained a human body, distinguishing good and bad.
I should seek the immortal Dharma of immortality.
As a verse says:
The six sense faculties are complete, and the wisdom mirror is also sharp.
But not seeking the Dharma of the Way, one vainly receives a body and wisdom.
Even beasts all have wisdom, desiring pleasure to indulge themselves.
But they do not know the skillful means, practicing good deeds for the Way.
Having already obtained a human body, but only indulging themselves.
Not knowing how to cultivate wholesome conduct, what is the difference between them and that?
Beings in the three evil paths cannot cultivate the path's activities.
Having already attained this human body, one should strive to benefit oneself.
The practitioner, having contemplated this,
then takes the person they love, whether male or female,

removes their clothing, lies them naked on the ground, and in front of them contemplates the corpse as if it were a corpse, single-mindedly and in samÄdhi observing this corpse, the mind greatly alarmed and fearful, destroying the mind attached to love.
This is a brief explanation of the contemplation of death as a preliminary practice for the nine contemplations.
Furthermore, the nine contemplations are of two kinds.
The first is for those with sharp faculties,
and the second is for those with dull faculties.
If a person with sharp faculties suspends their mind and contemplates the matter of a bloated corpse, etc., they will all attain accomplishment.

If a person with dull faculties suspends their mind and it does not succeed, they must go to where a person has just died, observe the characteristics of the corpse, and fix their mind on cultivating it.
When they see the characteristics clearly and the mental image is accomplished, then samÄdhi will arise.
Even if one later leaves the corpse, one still sees it as one imagines it.
The first is the thought of bloating.
The practitioner, facing the corpse, sees it bloated like a leather bag filled with wind, different from its original appearance.
In this body, there is no master, but the deluded consciousness controls the eyes and ears, and speaks.
Deceiving oneself with this, where will one go now?
Only seeing an empty house, bloated and stiff-necked.
This body's appearance is enchanting, with fine skin, red lips, white teeth, long eyes, a straight nose, and high eyebrows. Such a beautiful body confuses people's minds.
Now, only seeing bloating as good, where is it?
The characteristics of men and women cannot be recognized either.
Then, taking this appearance, observe the person I love.
Making this reproach, the mind of desire is a stinking bag, bloated and disgusting.
How can it be worth being attached to and sinking in this?
Think to yourself, My body has not escaped this dharma.
Single-mindedly in samÄdhi, remove worldly greed and love.
The second is the thought of decay.
The practitioner further contemplates a corpse, blown by the wind and exposed to the sun, becoming bloated and rotten on the ground.
The six parts of the body are shattered, and the five internal organs, filled with foul-smelling excrement and urine, are exposed.
What I am attached to is seen in this way as having nothing lovable or enjoyable.
I am deluded and deceived by this bag of excrement and thin skin.
Like a moth to a flame.
Only greedy for the bright colors, not caring about the disaster of burning the body.
I think of my body as being the same.
Not yet free from this dharma.
Single-mindedly in samÄdhi, removing worldly greed and love.
Third, the contemplation of blood and filth.
The practitioner further contemplates a corpse, seeing it broken apart, with pus and blood flowing everywhere from head to toe, staining everything.
Unclean, foul-smelling, putrid, and bloated, it is unapproachable.
What I love is seen in this way as having nothing lovable or enjoyable.
I am deluded and sit in this sinking and defiled impurity, what is there to enjoy?
I think of my body as not yet free from this dharma.
Single-minded samÄdhi eliminates worldly greed and love, the fourth being the thought of putrefaction.

The practitioner observes a dead body, gradually decaying over time due to wind, heat, and water, with worms and pus flowing out from the nine orifices on the body, the skin and flesh putrefying everywhere.
The stench spreads on the ground, the foul smell increasing. What I love is observed in this way, the beautiful appearance and fine features are due to this confusion.
Now seeing the stench is worse than excrement, how can one be greedy and attached?
Thinking to oneself, My body has not escaped this dharma, single-minded samÄdhi eliminates worldly greed and love.
The fifth being the thought of bluish discoloration.

The practitioner further observes a dead body, the pus and blood gradually drying up, the skin and flesh turning yellow and red, decaying and turning black and blue due to wind and sun, the foul smell increasing.
What I love is observed in this way, the color of peach blossoms deceiving me, now where is it?
Thinking to oneself, My body has not escaped this dharma, single-minded samÄdhi eliminates worldly greed and love, the sixth being the thought of being eaten.

The practitioner further observes the corpse being eaten by worms and maggots, with crows pecking out its eyes, foxes and dogs gnawing at it, tigers and wolves tearing it apart, the body mutilated and disfigured, falling apart and scattered, disgusting. The person I love, when viewed in this way, originally had a clean and well-dressed body, adorned with ornaments, and was self-indulgent.
Now, seeing it destroyed, the original appearance is all lost, and it is very disgusting.
I think of my own body, not yet free from this dharma, single-mindedly in samÄdhi, removing worldly greed and love.
Seven, scattered thoughts.

The practitioner further observes the corpse being torn apart by birds and beasts, the body broken and scattered, blown by the wind and exposed to the sun, the tendons severed, the bones separated, the head and torso lying in different places.
Where is the human form of the person I love, when viewed in this way?
I think of my own body, not yet free from this dharma, single-mindedly in samÄdhi, removing worldly greed and love.
Eight, the thought of bones.
The practitioner further observes the corpse, with the skin and flesh all gone, only seeing white bones.
Seeing bones has two aspects.
First, seeing the tendons connected.
Second, the tendons exhausted, the bones separated.
There are two kinds.
One is stained by other blood and grease,
and the other is as white as a shell or a conch.
The skull of the person I love, when viewed in this way, is more frightening than a hard stone.
The soft and delicate touch will all be lost in an instant.
Thinking that my body is not exempt from this, I single-mindedly enter samÄdhi to remove worldly greed and attachment.
The ninth contemplation is on burning.
The practitioner goes to a charnel ground,
and sees many dead bodies burned together, with the belly bursting open and fat oozing out, exploding with smoke and stench, extremely frightening.
Or sees only white bones burning, with flames penetrating through, the firewood exhausted and the fire extinguished, the form the same as gray soil.
Even if not burned or buried, it will still return to destruction.
The body of the person I love, when viewed in this way, is completely exhausted, even worse than a weapon.
Bathing, perfuming, flowers, powder, adornments, soft, plump, delicate body, pure and warm, flattering and deceitful.
Using this to deceive people, now all destroyed, where is it in the end?
Reflecting on oneself, one has not yet escaped this dharma, and with single-minded samÄdhi, one eliminates worldly greed and love. The second clarifies the nine visualizations for counteracting.
The practitioner, having cultivated the nine visualizations and become proficient,
Must increase the visualizations and cultivate them again to make the contemplation skillful and effective.
Whenever one contemplates, the mind immediately accords with samÄdhi.
Contemplating the mind and holding it without a scattered intention.
This can then break the six desires and eliminate worldly greed and love.
The six desires are:
First, the desire for form.
Second, the desire for appearance.
Third, the desire for demeanor and manner.
Fourth, the desire for speech and sound.
Fifth, the desire for smoothness.
Sixth, the desire for human characteristics.
Within these six desires, they can give rise to six kinds of attachment.
The desire for form is when someone is attached to the color red.
If it is red and white, yellow and white, black, red and black, blue, blue and white, or peach blossom color.
Ignorant fools, upon seeing these colors, are drowned and confused by them.
If it is the desire for appearance, there are people.
But they are attached to physical appearance, with a face like a full moon.
With beautiful eyes, high eyebrows, a slender waist, and slender fingers, their excellent characteristics are upright and dignified.
The mind is then confused and attached.
The desire for demeanor refers to someone who is attached to demeanor, manner, walking and standing, raising eyebrows, frowning, smiling, and being flirtatious, and then gives rise to defilement.

The desire for speech refers to someone who only loves the sound of speech. If they hear skillful words, flowery speech that accords with the mind and captures the essence, with clear and elegant tones, singing praises and eulogies that move the heart,
The desire for smoothness refers to someone who only loves the softness of the body, with plump skin that is radiant, like cotton.
When cold, the body is warm; when hot, the body is cool.
Massaging, receiving, and wearing fragrant incense on the body.
Ordinary feelings are submerged and endangered by this.
The mixed desires refer to
someone who is attached to all five things.
The desire for human characteristics refers to
someone who is not attached to any of the five things,
but is only attached to human characteristics, whether male or female. Even if they see the above five things,
If one does not obtain the beloved person, one is still not attached.
If one encounters a pleasing person, one can abandon what the world values and suddenly lose one's life.
In this way, the six desires deceive sentient beings from life to life.
They sink and drown in birth and death, and are submerged in the three evil paths.
One does not attain liberation.
If one is able to skillfully cultivate the nine visualizations to eliminate them,
then the six desires will be destroyed and scattered, and one will quickly attain nirvana.
Why is this so?
The initial visualization of death breaks the desires of deportment and speech.ğŸ”½Next, the visualizations of bloating, decay, and being eaten break the desire for physical appearance.
Next, the visualizations of being smeared with blood, turning blue and black, and festering mostly break the desire for color.
Next, the visualizations of bones and being burned mostly remove the desire for smoothness.

The nine visualizations eliminate the miscellaneous desires and the desire for the characteristics of the beloved person. The visualization of being eaten, scattered, and bones specifically removes the desire for the characteristics of a person. In the scattered white bones, one does not see a person to be attached to.
By means of these nine visualizations, one is able to break the bonds of desire, and anger and delusion are also diminished.
Because the three poisons are weak, the mountain of ninety-eight kinds of afflictions all move.
Gradually progressing on the path, using the vajra samÄdhi to destroy the mountain of afflictions and attain the path of the three vehicles.
Although the nine contemplations are impure meditations, they are able to accomplish great matters.
It is like a corpse in the great ocean, a drowning person can rely on it to cross.
Fourth, the inclusion of dharmas.
This nine-part contemplation takes the form of the desire realm body and the aggregate of form as its object.
It is also a part of the mindfulness of the body.
It is either included in the desire realm or the first and second dhyÄnas.
A person who has not yet separated from desire and has a scattered mind attains the desire realm.
A person who has separated from desire attains the form realm.
The eight contemplations such as bloating and so forth are included in the first and second dhyÄnas of the desire realm.
The contemplation of pure bones is included in the first, second, and fourth dhyÄnas of the desire realm.
In the third dhyÄna, there is much bliss, so there is no such contemplation.
Fifth, the nine contemplations leading to the path.
Cultivating the nine contemplations is of two kinds.

If one practices this based on events, one will only be able to subdue the bonds of the desire realm. Later, one should separately cultivate the ten contemplations to eliminate the views and thoughts, and accomplish the path of no more learning.
Second, if one skillfully cultivates the nine contemplations, one will be equipped with the ten contemplations, and enter the truth from events.
Then one will not be bothered by separately cultivating the ten contemplations based on other approaches.
Why is this so?
When the practitioner observes a person at the time of death, their movements and speech suddenly cease in an instant.
The body swells up, rots, decays, and disperses, each changing into something different.
This is impermanence.
If one is attached to this impermanent and decaying body, it is suffering.
If it is impermanent, suffering, and not in control, then it is no-self.
Because of being impure, impermanent, suffering, and no-self,
one cannot take pleasure in the world.
Contemplate the body like this.
Even though food is in the mouth, brain and saliva flow down and combine with saliva to form a flavor.
But swallowing is no different than vomiting.
Below in the stomach, it becomes feces.
This is the contemplation of the impurity of food.
Using these nine contemplations to contemplate the body as impermanent and changing, moment by moment ceasing,
This is the contemplation of death.
Using these nine contemplations to be disgusted with worldly pleasures,
Knowing that afflictions are severed is peaceful and tranquil extinction.
This is the contemplation of severance.
Using these nine contemplations to block all afflictions is the contemplation of separation.
Because these nine contemplations are disgusted with the world,
Knowing the five aggregates cease,
No longer needing to be born in this place is peaceful.
This is the contemplation of exhaustion.
If one can skillfully cultivate the nine contemplations, one will possess the ten contemplations and sever the delusions of views and thoughts.
One should know that such a person will definitely proceed to the path of the three vehicles.
Furthermore, in the MahÄyÄna it is said that if one skillfully cultivates the nine contemplations, it opens the door of the mindfulness of the body.
The mindfulness of the body opens the door of the three mindfulnesses.
The four mindfulnesses open the door of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment open the door of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Because one enters nirvÄá¹‡a, all sorrows and sufferings cease.
Because the bodhisattva has compassion for sentient beings,
Although one can enter nirvana through the nine contemplations,
one still does not take the ultimate truth as one's realization.
Why is this so?
If there were no characteristics of taste in form, sentient beings would not be attached to form.
If there were no characteristics of separation in form, one would not be able to attain liberation from form.
Because there are characteristics of taste in form, sentient beings become attached to form.
Because there are characteristics of separation in form, sentient beings can attain liberation from form.
But taste is not the same as separation, and separation is not the same as taste.
There is no place of liberation apart from taste, and no taste apart from the place of liberation.
One should know that form is neither bound nor liberated.
At that time, one does not follow birth and death, nor does one realize nirvana.
But with great compassion, one takes pity on all sentient beings.
Within this contemplation of impurity, one perfects all the Buddha's teachings.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra says:
The nine contemplations are the MahÄyÄna of the bodhisattva.ğŸ”½Next, the eight mindfulnesses are explained.
As for the eight mindfulnesses,
First, mindfulness of the Buddha; second, mindfulness of the Dharma;
Third, mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha;
Fourth, mindfulness of the precepts;
Fifth, mindfulness of renunciation;
Sixth, mindfulness of the heavens;
Seventh, mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation;
Eighth, mindfulness of death.
These eight are collectively called mindfulness because
In a single-pointed mind, one recollects and holds them without forgetting.
This is called mindfulness.
Now, the explanation of the eight mindfulnesses has three meanings.
First, clarifying the purpose of the teaching;
Second, clarifying the cultivation and realization; third, clarifying the characteristics of the path to be taken.
First, clarifying the purpose of the teaching;
The Buddha's disciples in secluded places, empty houses, charnel grounds, mountains, forests, and wilderness,
Skillfully cultivate the nine visualizations, externally disgusted with the impurity of the body, and think like this:
How can I take this inferior, impure, stinking bag of excrement and urine to follow me?
At that time, suddenly startled and frightened, the body hair stands on end.
And for the evil mÄras, they take on various forms and colors to frighten them.
Wishing to cause their path to retreat and disappear.
Therefore, one should contemplate the Buddha.
Next, after the nine contemplations, the eight recollections are explained to eliminate fear.
As it is said in the sutra:
The Buddha told the monks:
If there is a fearful mind in a secluded place,
at that time one should contemplate the Buddha and fear will immediately disappear.
If one does not contemplate the Buddha, one should contemplate the Dharma and fear will be removed.
If one does not contemplate the Dharma, one should contemplate the Sangha and fear will be removed.
Therefore, it is known that the three recollections are taught to eliminate fear.
Question:
The sutra speaks of the three recollections as causes and conditions to eliminate fear. What about the following five recollections?
Answer:
If a monk himself practices giving and upholding the precepts, fear will be removed.
Why is it so?
If one violates the precepts, one fears falling into hell.
If one is stingy and greedy, one fears falling into the realm of hungry ghosts.
And in poverty, one thinks to oneself:
I have this pure morality and giving.
Then one is delighted. The heavens above are all the fruits of giving and upholding the precepts.
I also have this kind of merit and virtue.
Therefore, I contemplate the heavens.
It can also cause fear.
It does not arise within the sixteen aspects of contemplation.
When contemplating the inhalation and exhalation of breath, even subtle mental awareness ceases.
How much more so for fear, which is a coarse awareness.
Contemplating death is contemplating the momentary arising and ceasing of the five aggregates.
Since birth, it has always been accompanied by death.
Why be afraid of death now?
Although these five contemplations do not specifically mention it,
one should know that they are for deeply eliminating fear.
Why is this?
Contemplating the merits of others to eliminate fear is difficult.
Contemplating one's own merits to eliminate fear is easy.
For this reason, it is not specifically mentioned.
Second, clarifying the cultivation and realization of the eight contemplations.
As for contemplating the Buddha, if the practitioner is in an araá¹‡ya,
if the mind has fear, one should contemplate the Buddha.
The Buddha is the TathÄgata, Arhat, Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha,
up to the BhagavÄn.
Endowed with the ten epithets.
The thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks.
Great compassion, the ten powers, the four fearlessnesses, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha.
Wisdom, light, spiritual powers, and immeasurable abilities to save immeasurable sentient beings in the ten directions.
This is my great teacher who saves all. What fear do I have?
Single-mindedly recollecting, fear is immediately removed.
Second, contemplating the Dharma.
The practitioner should contemplate this Dharma.
Skillfully emerging, attaining present-life fruits, free from vexation.
Not waiting for the right time, able to reach good places, penetrating without obstruction.
Skillfully emerging means skillfully expounding the two truths without contradiction.
This Dharma is able to emerge from the two extremes, thus it is called skillfully emerging.
Attaining present-life fruits means that the teachings of non-Buddhists all lack present-life fruits.

Only in the Buddha's teachings do causes and conditions arise in succession.ğŸ”½Namely, because of upholding precepts purely, one attains a non-regretful mind. Because of attaining a non-regretful mind, one gives rise to the joy of the Dharma.
Because of giving rise to the joy of the Dharma, one attains mental bliss.
Because one attains mental joy, one is able to concentrate the mind.
Because the mind is concentrated, one attains true knowledge.
Because one attains true knowledge, one attains disgust.ğŸ”½Because one attains disgust, one attains detachment.
Because of detachment, one attains liberation.
Because of the retribution of liberation, one attains nirvana.
This is called attaining the fruits of this world.
Free from afflictions means free from the afflictions of the three poisons and birth and death.
Not waiting for the right time means
that for the non-Buddhists to receive the Dharma, they must wait for the right time.
The Buddha's teachings are not like this. It is like firewood encountering fire and immediately burning, not waiting for the right time.
Reaching a good place means that if one practices the Buddha's teachings, one will surely reach the blissful fruits of humans and gods and the place of nirvana of the three vehicles.
Penetrating without obstruction means that because one attains the three Dharma seals, one penetrates without obstruction.
What should I fear if I cultivate such dharmas?
If one single-mindedly recollects, fear will be removed.
The third recollection is of the Sangha.
The practitioner should recollect the Sangha.
The Sangha is the assembly of the Buddha's disciples.
Possessing the five parts of the Dharma body.
Among them are four pairs, eight groups, and twenty-seven people.
They should receive offerings, worship, and service.
They are the unsurpassed field of merit in the world.
Namely, the Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas,
the Saá¹…gha of pratyekabuddhas,
and the Saá¹…gha of bodhisattvas.
Their wisdom is immeasurable, able to rescue from suffering and deliver sentient beings.
Such a holy assembly is my true companion. What fear is there?
Single-mindedly recollecting them, fear is immediately dispelled.
Fourth, the mindfulness of precepts.
The practitioner should recollect these precepts.
They can restrain all evil and are a place of peace and security. There are two kinds of precepts within this:
namely, defiled precepts and undefiled precepts.
There are also two kinds:
First, the precepts of restraining evil;
second, the precepts that accompany concentration.
The precepts of restraining evil can restrain all evil and bring peace to the body.
The precepts that accompany concentration can restrain the afflictions and bring inner joy to the mind.
The undefiled precepts can break through the fundamental evil of ignorance and bring the joy of liberation.
I cultivate such dharmas, what is there to fear?
Single-mindedly recollecting, fear is immediately dispelled.
The fifth recollection is of relinquishment.
The practitioner should recollect:
Relinquishment is of two kinds.
One is the relinquishment of giving.
The other is the relinquishment of afflictions.
Relinquishment of giving is of two kinds.
One is the relinquishment of wealth.
The other is the relinquishment of the Dharma.
These two kinds of relinquishment are all called relinquishment.
They are the root of all wholesome dharmas.
The practitioner should think to himself: Since I have had a body, I have also had the merit of relinquishment and giving.
What is there to fear?
Single-mindedly recollecting, fear is immediately dispelled.
The sixth recollection is of the gods.

The practitioner should recollect the Four Heavenly Kings up to the Heaven of Freely Partaking of Others' Pleasures. Those gods and others all because of the wholesome roots of precepts and giving in the past.
They attained rebirth in those places and experienced long nights of happiness.
The wholesome dharmas protect and recollect us. We should also recollect.
There are four kinds of gods.
One is called the named god.
Second, being born in the heavens.
Third, being pure in the heavens.
Fourth, being born with meaning in the heavens.
Such heavenly rewards are pure.
If I have the virtue of precepts and giving,
when I give up my life I will surely be born in those places.
What is there to fear?
Single-mindedly recollecting, fear is immediately removed.
Seventh, mindfulness of the breath.
As explained in the first gate of the sixty special qualities above.
If the practitioner's mind is frightened, they should regulate their breath, be mindful of the breath coming and going, and be aware of it up to ten times.
Then they should speak and be mindful of the breath.
In this way, up to sixteen spirits will return.
Single-mindedly being mindful of the breath, fear is immediately removed.
Next, be mindful of death.
Death is of two kinds.
First, dying by oneself.
Second, dying due to other causes and conditions.
These two kinds of death always follow this body.

If it is said that ceasing exists apart from arising, abiding would also be destroyed, and the meaning of the three characteristics would be lost.
If it is apart from arising, then there is nothing to cease.
